Content.Name: Course Detail
Content.Title: Course Descriptions
Content.Abstract: BYU-Idaho Online Family History course descriptions
Content.BodyCopy:
FHGEN 111 Introduction to Family History Research, Part One: Record Groups and Methodology

This course consists of the following lessons:

  1. Introduction of Family History
  2. Understanding Evidence
  3. Complied Sources
  4. Vital Records
  5. Census Records
  6. Religious and Cemetery Records
  7. Newspaper, City Directories, Country and Town Histories
  8. Probate Records
  9. Land Records
  10. Military Records
  11. Immigration and Naturalization Records
  12. Court and Tax Records

FHGEN 112 Introduction to Family History Research, Part Two: Analysis of Research Evidence

Prerequisites: FHGEN 111

This course consists of the following lessons:

  1. Immigrant Origins Post-1850
  2. Immigrant Origins Pre-1850
  3. Professional Crednetials
  4. Organizing Your Research
  5. The Research Process
  6. Pedigree Analysis
  7. Evidence Analysis
  8. Source Citations
  9. Finding Aids, Maps and Gazetteers
  10. History and Customs
  11. Repositories
  12. Record Substitutions

FHGEN 120 Internet and Computer Skills

This course consists of the following lessons:

  1. Internet Searches for Genealogy
  2. RootsMagic Part 1
  3. RootsMagic Part 2
  4. FamilySearch Part1
  5. FamilySearch Part2
  6. Social Media for Genealogy
  7. Wiki
  8. Ancestry.com
  9. Genealogical Databases
  10. Reference Sources
  11. Computer Skills
  12. Applying Internet and Computer Skills

FHGEN 130 Paleography

This course consists of the following lessons:

  1. Introduction to Paleography
  2. Transcriptions, Extracts and Abstracts
  3. Penmanship in America-Post Colonial Era
  4. Penmanship in America Colonial Era
  5. Advanced Secretary Hand
  6. Reading and Deciphering Records
  7. Dates, Calendars, Numbers and Latin
  8. Contextual Clues
  9. Old English Paleography
  10. Nordic Paleography
  11. Final Project

FHGEN 140 Genealogical Writing

This course consists of the following lessons:

  1. Professional Writing Skills 1
  2. Professional Writing Skills 2
  3. Elements of a Geneological Report
  4. Evidence Analysis in a Research Report
  5. Complex Evidence
  6. Editing a Genealogical Report
  7. Writing Family Histories, Biographies and Autobiographies
  8. Complied Reports
  9. Genealogical Articles
  10. Writing Ethics
  11. Publishing a Family History
  12. Portfolio

 
FHGEN 160 The Family and Society

This course consists of the following lessons: 

  1. Records that Reveal The Family
  2. European Legacies
  3. Colonial Diversity
  4. Revolutions Political, Economic and Familial
  5. African American and Native American Families
  6. Industrialization and Immigration
  7. Companionate Family
  8. Great Depression
  9. Impact of War
  10. Golden Age
  11. Increasing Individualism
  12. Current Trends

FHGEN 211 Research Methodology, Part 1

This course consists of six research projects, each of which focuses on an immigrant from a different country including:

  1. Italy
  2. Germany
  3. France
  4. Canada
  5. England
  6. Sweden

Students will learn and practice effective genealogical research methodology as they identify research problems, plan and execute strategy, compile and analyze evidence, assemble documents, cite sources and produce a professional and well-organized report. 

 
FHGEN 212 Research Methodology, Part 2

Prerequisites: FGHEN 211

This course consists of six research projects that require use of a variety of records and involve different areas of the United States.  Four of these projects are provided by the instructor; students select the other two projects.  Students will learn and practice effective genealogical research methodology as they identify key records to use in solving research problems; plan and execute strategy; compile and evaluate evidence; record and organize information; cite sources; and prepare a professional and well-organized research report and research calendar.

 
FHGEN 251A Geographic Specialization Course 1: U.S. Regions Research, Part 1

Prerequisites: Previous or concurrent enrollment in FHGEN 130 and 211

This course consists of the following lessons:

  1. Historical Background Northeast
  2. Big City Methodology
  3. New Englad States Resources
  4. Mid-Atlantic States Resources
  5. Northeastern States Final Project
  6. Northwestern States Final Project
  7. Historical Background Midwest
  8. Native American Methodology
  9. Midwestern States Resources
  10. Great Plains States Resources
  11. Mideastern and Great Plains Final Project
  12. Midwestern and Great Plains Final Project

 
FHGEN 251B Geographic Specialization Course 1: British Isles Research, Part 1

Prerequisites: Previous or concurrent enrollment in FHGEN 130 and 211

This course consists of the following lessons:

  1. Fundamentals of English and Welsh Reserach
  2. Census Records
  3. Civil Registration Records
  4. Church of England Records
  5. Nonconformist Records
  6. Probates
  7. Parish Chest and Poor Law Records
  8. Methodology
  9. British Military Records
  10. Property and Tax Records
  11. Additional Records
  12. Research Project

 
FHGEN 251C Geographic Specialization Course 1: German Research Part 1

Prerequisites: Previous or concurrent enrollment in FHGEN 130 and 211

This course consists of the following lessons:

  1. Outline Fundamentals
  2. Handwriting and Genealogical Terms
  3. Emigration and Immigration
  4. Historical Events
  5. Gazetteers, Record Jurisdictions and Maps
  6. Calendars and Dates
  7. Religious Records
  8. Civil Registration Records
  9. Internet Sites and Databases
  10. Beginning Research Methodology
  11. Naming Practices
  12. Directed Research

 
FHGEN 251D Geographic Specialization Course 1: Nordic Research Part 1

Prerequisites: Previous or concurrent enrollment in FHGEN 130 and 211

This course consists of the following lessons:

  1. Nordic Naming Patterns and Practices
  2. Nordic Handwriting and Gelealogical Terms
  3. Basic Fundamentals of Swedish Research
  4. Swedish Church Records
  5. Swedish Civil Registration, Census Records and Databases
  6. Swedish Basic Methodology and Compiled Sources
  7. Swedish Military and Tax Records
  8. Swedish Court Records
  9. Intermediate Swedish Research Strategies
  10. Finnish Fundamentals, History and Local Surveys
  11. Finnish Church Records and Methodology
  12. Swedish or Finnish Final Project

 
FHGEN 252A Geographic Specialization Course 2: U.S. Regions Research, Part 2

Prerequisites: FHGEN 251A

This course consists of the following lessons:

  1. Historical Background of the Southern States
  2. African American Methodology
  3. Mid-South States Resources
  4. Gulf-South States Resources
  5. Southern States Final Project
  6. Historical Background of Western States
  7. Researching LDS Ancestry
  8. Mountain West States Resources
  9. Pacific States Resources
  10. Western States Final Project

 
FHGEN 252B Geographic Specialization Course 2: British Isles Research, Part 2

Prerequisites: FHGEN 251B

This course consists of the following lessons:

  1. Tracing Scottish and Irish Immigrant Origins
  2. Historical, Geographical and Archival Foundation for Scottish Research
  3. Scotland Census Records
  4. Scotland Civil Registration Records
  5. Church of Scotland Records
  6. Scotland Nonconformist Records
  7. Scotland Probate, Land and Property Records
  8. Historical, Geographical, and Archival Foundation for Irish Research
  9. Ireland Census Records
  10. Ireland Civil Registration Records
  11. Ireland Church Records
  12. Ireland Probate, Land and Property Records 

FHGEN 252C Geographic Specialization Course 2: German Research, Part 2

Prerequisites: FHGEN 251C

This course consists of the following lessons:

  1. Records Other Than Vital
  2. Advanced Research Methodology
  3. Archives and Repositories 
  4. German Society
  5. PreuBen West
  6. PreuBen East
  7. Württemburg and Baden
  8. Bayern, Pfalz, Elsass Lothringen
  9. Mecklenburg, Oldenburg, and Braunschweig
  10. Hessen, Lippe and Waldeck
  11. Königreich Sachsen, Thüringen and Hamburg, Bremen, Lübeck
  12. Final Project

 
FHGEN 252D Geographic Specialization Course 2: Nordic Research, Part 2

Prerequisites: FHGEN 251D

This course consists of the following lessons:

  1. Danish Church and Civil Registration Records
  2. Danish Census and Emigration
  3. Basic Danish Methodology
  4. Danish Probate, Military and Tax Records
  5. Intermediate Danish Methodology
  6. Danish Research Project
  7. Norwegian Church Records
  8. Norwegian Census and Emigration Records
  9. Norwegian Gazetteers, Maps, Farm Books, and Methodology
  10. Norwegian Probate, Tax, and Matrikkel Records
  11. Norwegian Genealogical Collections and Printed Sources
  12. Norwegian Research Project

FHGEN 270 Genealogy as a Business

This course consists of the following lessons:

  1. Career Options for the Genealogist
  2. Is Becoming a Professional Genealogist Right for You?
  3. Create and Structure a Business
  4. Licenses, Taxes and Insurance
  5. Market Your Business, Part 1
  6. Market Your Business, Part 2
  7. Obtain and Manage Your Clientele
  8. Operate Your Business, Part 1
  9. Operate Your Business, Part 2
  10. Accounting and Finance
  11. Work With People
  12. Ethics and Professionalism

 
FHGEN 299 Capstone: Professional Research

Prerequisites: Previous or concurrent enrollment in FHGEN 212

This course helps students prepare applications for submission to the two credentialing organizations for professional genealogists: the Board for Certification of Genealogists (BCG) and the International Commission for the Accreditation of Professional Genealogists (ICAPGen).  Students will complete all of the major components to fulfill each organization's application requirements (some of the requirements have been modified in the course to enable students to complete the projects within one semester).  Both credentialing processes test a genealogist's competence in research, analysis, and reporting skills.
